bestBHT.bht: The apostles spoke boldly in the Lord, relying on their confidence in God and the word of His grace. They preached fearlessly in the name of the Lord Jesus, who confirmed their message by granting miraculous signs and wonders. These miracles were a sign of God's authority over their work. Undeterred by dangers, the apostles boldly proclaimed the Gospel, finding their support in Christ. This period of opportunity allowed Paul and Barnabas to bear witness to the word of His grace through their preaching and the signs performed.

Henry Alford: speaking boldly in the Lord... grounded on confidence in the Lord."
By the Lord here is meant GOD.
God, and the word of His grace.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: speaking boldly in the Lord—rather, 'in dependence on the Lord,' that is, on their glorified Head.
who gave testimony to the word of his grace—a notable definition of the Gospel, whose whole burden is GRACE.
and granted—'granting,' that is, who confirmed the Gospel by granting miraculous attestation to it.
Albert Barnes: Persecution and opposition may be attended often with signal success to the gospel.
Spake boldly in the Lord - In the cause of the Lord Jesus, or in his name and by his authority.
The conversion of sinners accomplished by him is always a testimony as decided as it is cheering to the labors and messages of his servants.
Marvin Vincent: In the Lord. Lit., upon [επι] the Lord : in reliance on him.
John Calvin: They stood stoutly, and through rare constancy and courage counted all dangers as nothing, until they were compelled by violence to depart to another place.
The Lord showed in miracles his power openly before all the people, which greatly emboldened Paul and Barnabas.
Those miracles which came from God at any time did never tend to any other end but that the gospel might have his perfect and full authority.
Philip Schaff: Their patient bravery found its grand support in the protection of Christ.
Undismayed by dangers ever thickening around them, the undaunted apostles boldly proclaimed the Gospel.
The miracles were wrought by Christ as a sign of His approval of His servants' work, apparently after the multitude had been gathered into His fold.
Archibald T. Robertson: After the persecution and vindication there was a season of great opportunity which Paul and Barnabas used to the full, 'speaking boldly' (παρρησιαζομενο as in Acts 13:46 at Antioch in Pisidia, 'in the Lord' (επ τω κυριω), upon the basis of the Lord Jesus as in Acts 4:17."
And the Lord Jesus 'bore witness to the word of his grace' as he always does, 'granting signs and wonders to be done by their hands' (διδοντ σημεια κα τερατα γινεσθα δια των χειρων αυτων)."
The time of peace could not last forever with such a work of grace as this. A second explosion of persecution was bound to come and some of the MSS. actually have εκ δευτερου (a second time).
John Gill: speaking boldly in the Lord; using great freedom of speech, and showing great courage and intrepidity of mind; speaking out, without fear, the doctrines of the Gospel, in the name of the Lord"
to this he bore witness, by giving it success, notwithstanding the opposition made against it, and by miracles wrought in confirmation of it"

these miraculous works were not wrought by the power of the apostles, but by the power of God; they were only instruments by whom they were done; it was owing to a grant from the Lord, and to his power, that they were performed.

bhtAttempts.bht: The apostles spoke boldly in the Lord, relying on their confidence in God and the word of His grace. They preached fearlessly in the name of the Lord Jesus, who confirmed their message by granting miraculous signs and wonders to be done by their hands. This season of opportunity, after the persecution and vindication, allowed Paul and Barnabas to proclaim the Gospel on the basis of the Lord Jesus, bearing witness to the word of His grace. The miracles performed were a clear sign of God's approval and authority over their work. Despite the dangers and opposition they faced, the undaunted apostles boldly proclaimed the Gospel, finding their grand support and protection in Christ.

The apostles spoke boldly in the Lord, relying on their confidence in God and the word of His grace. In the name of the Lord Jesus, they fearlessly proclaimed the Gospel, witnessing to the word of His grace and confirming it through miraculous signs and wonders. These miracles were a testimony to the approval and authority of God. Undeterred by dangers, the apostles courageously proclaimed the Gospel, finding their support in the protection of Christ. This season of opportunity allowed Paul and Barnabas to bear witness to the powerful work of God.

In Acts 14:3, the apostles boldly spoke in the Lord, grounded in their confidence in God and the word of His grace. Their preaching was in dependence on the Lord, their glorified Head. By bearing witness to the word of His grace, they confirmed the Gospel through miraculous attestation. This notable definition of the Gospel emphasizes its core message of grace. The Lord granted signs and wonders to be done by their hands, affirming the authority of their work.

In their proclamation, the apostles fearlessly spoke in the Lord, relying on their confidence in God and the word of His grace. Their boldness was grounded in their dependence on the Lord Jesus, their glorified Head, and His confirmation of the Gospel through miraculous signs and wonders. The miracles served as a notable demonstration of the authority and approval of God. Undeterred by dangers, the apostles steadfastly and courageously proclaimed the Gospel, finding their support and protection in Christ.
